reviews.author: David Bax

reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: The women do not suffer their deaths with any less violence. Three important men, named, with histories and layers, die too. The movie pauses and allows each of their passings a solemn grace, as dictated by its audience, single-minded and insatiable.
reviews.author: Tara Thorne

reviews.text: The film and the latest incarnation of Jackman as Wolverine is entertaining and meets expectations. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Oswaldo Betancourt Lozano

reviews.text: Logan's virtue is that it distances itself completely from previous films. There are no superheroes, impressive costumes or big demonstrations of mutant power. Without a doubt, the best of the genre. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Lucero Solórzano

reviews.text: Offering a touch of Mad Max, some tense humour, a glimpse of the classic Western Shane for obvious reasons and Hugh's most glowering performance in X-Men history, this is a fitting and surprisingly moving... finale to the Wolverine saga.
reviews.author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley

reviews.text: This is a well-acted film with decent action scenes. It isn't really my cup of tea, but that doesn't take away from the fact this movie is well made. I just wish they had made it less depressing.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Jackman and Stewart are why Logan works-why the film doesn't feel like a cheap exercise in bloody violence, and its subversion of typical superhero-movie tropes feels organic.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Another expensive throwaway aimed at milking money out of people who still read comic books. Color it stupid.
reviews.author: Rex Reed

reviews.text: Logan is a perfect bookend to Hugh Jackman's years of playing the role. To see him go out on such an exuberant high is much more than anyone could have asked for.
reviews.author: David Fontana

reviews.text: An intimate story of few characters, without exaggerated digital effects, and focused on the mortality of its protagonists and the consequences of their violent acts. Logan definitely couldn't have had a better goodbye. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Logan is a sign that it's possible to make mature films with superheroes, with themes of real emotional resonance. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rafael Paz

reviews.text: Strips away the spandex, the posse and the chaos, distilling the story down to the essence of the man, Logan. What's left is the agony and the ecstasy of mutanthood.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: A film with adult themes such as illness, death wish, contradictions between longings and reality, and confronts them in a cruel and visceral way with a tender, memorable and heartbreaking ending. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Fernando Galván

reviews.text: Maybe it has 20 minutes more, but the pieces are placed to, within its genre, have an anthology film for the character, the closing of this saga manages to leave a mark on the viewer. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Adrián Ruiz

reviews.text: A story with little action that lacks the epic brilliance of the character. Finally the worst happens: the film becomes long and boring. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pilar Ayuso

reviews.text: A dark, tragic and hopeful story that leaves us with a bittersweet feeling because it's best solo film of the character, and even within the X-Men universe. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Iván Belmont

reviews.text: Before it settles down as a cross between 'Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome' and 'Shane' it's a pretty joyless slog, one CG-enhanced battle after another ... Dafne Keen as Wolvie's ward goes full feral.
reviews.author: Glenn Lovell

reviews.text: The tonal shift for Marvel, however, is welcome, and no character from its stable better suits the Western mould (the 1953 classic Shane is referenced heavily). Conventional as it is, overall Mangold finds room for more strikingly inventive set pieces.
reviews.author: Hilary A White

reviews.text: The super-violent Logan is just slashed brisket.
reviews.author: Camilla Long

reviews.text: After the 140-minute running time I felt as exhausted as Wolverine.
reviews.author: Henry Fitzherbert

reviews.text: Full of grainy light and bloody violence that is shadowed by sorrowful regret, James Mangold's movie creates a sober and deeply satisfying finale for Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, the snarling centrepiece of so many X-Men movies.
reviews.author: Craig Mathieson

reviews.text: It's as if Quentin Tarantino took the reigns of the X-Men franchise and offered his own perspective on Wolverine and Professor Xavier.
reviews.author: John Hanlon

reviews.text: Jackman's last and best turn as Wolverine shows us something new: a superhero, aging and past his prime. (Splice Today)
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: For fans of the "X-Men," this is easily the best entry in the series in some time, a film that's more interested in the characters than in the special effects.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: Tightly plotted and ruthlessly bloodthirsty, this is an impressive return to form for the X-Men franchise.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: It's the heartfelt performance by Jackman that keeps this last Logan superhero film on the right track.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Elegiac conclusion to Wolverine's solo trilogy...
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: On this rich and emotionally satisfying evidence, lower budget, intimate and psychological takes on the incredible just might be the way forward.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: "Owing to its agitated hero's misfortunes through the ages, this is a film that's acutely aware of the dangers of emotional exploitation, and it spares its audience a similar fate."
reviews.author: Fiona Williams

reviews.text: The Dark Knight of the X-Men film universe.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: Gives Hugh Jackman's Wolfie a smoothly-executed but hard-R sendoff that arguably represents the high point of the actor's nearly two-decade run in the role.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Drawing from the pages of comics written in 2008 and 2009, Mangold and his team have created a script that more about human connection than silly, over-the-top fighting.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: The morose nihilism and all-around joylessness come to stink of adolescent posturing. This "comic book movie for adults" feels like one of the genre's most juvenile entries.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Stripped of their pen and ink testosterone, we can see them as human. It's not as sexy as ripped muscles and lycra tights, but it's as real as the genre can get without sacrificing our inner child on the cold altar of hard facts and undeniable mortality.
reviews.author: Katherine Monk

reviews.text: ...eschews invincibility in favor of human frailty.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: There's much to like in Logan, despite the bumpy landing. It reminds us that comic book franchises can aspire to deeper emotions and more complex relationships.
reviews.author: Jason Di Rosso

reviews.text: The best adaptation ever made of the X-Men universe and the best Wolverine film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nicolás Ruiz

reviews.text: A great action film, hard but penetrable, rigid but anti-static, violent but entertaning. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: Jackman's solemn performance matches perfectly with the surprises Mangold has in store during the emotional and action-packed farewell to an iconic hero.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: Jackman gives Logan a withering rage that seems heartfelt, not hammy; Stewart is touching in his enraged befuddlement; and Keen, who resembles here what Katie Holmes might look like if she were Carrie, has a feral intensity.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: Whenever the filmmakers have a choice between cruelly slaughtering characters and letting them live, they almost always choose the cruel path.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: [Director] Mangold drags [Wolverine] - much older, if not much wiser - into a Western, and ends up with the best superhero movie in recent memory.
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: When is the last time you walked out of a superhero film and was just speechless?
reviews.author: Gabi Zietsman

reviews.text: With Logan, Fox has cornered the market on R-rated superhero movies, following Deadpool with another adults-only comic-book flick. (Your move, DC.)
reviews.author: Annlee Ellingson

reviews.text: Mangold gives us a lean, focused story that doesn't involve any convoluted plots about evil global plans. Instead it's an elegiac tale about a man coming to terms with his life.
reviews.author: Beth Accomando

reviews.text: Logan gets its strength from its heartpounding action scenes and its heart-breaking personal moments.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: A down-to-earth title for a movie that holsters comic book camp and draws instead on classic Westerns.
reviews.author: Sharon Eberson

reviews.text: If the previous films focussed on Wolverine's superior healing abilities and fighting skills, Mangold has finally cracked the code with the third film -- it's the humane side of Wolverine/Logan that was always the most interesting thing about him.
reviews.author: Aakash Karkare

reviews.text: Logan does go defiantly against the grain by favouring melancholic mood and themes of mortality and deterioration over inflated, end-of-the-world stakes or grandiose action pyrotechnics.
reviews.author: Jessica Kiang

reviews.text: Did I get closure? No! I don't think I could ever say goodbye to Wolverine and Jackman (sorry, I can't separate the two).
reviews.author: Debashine Thangevelo

reviews.text: Logan's superb depiction of sorrow, of deadening dejection, of the awareness of mortality on multiple planes, rises far above Mangold's ready embrace of influence.
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: In the way it explores the inescapable nature of violence and its long-term effects, Logan is the Unforgiven of superhero cinema.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Dark, darkly funny farewell to the Wolverine. Stewart steals scenes left and right. Caliban and the kid are terrific. Come back, Wolvie.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: This is one of the finest comics-to-screen adaptations ever.
reviews.author: Rashid Irani

reviews.text: This isn't just a great comic book movie, isn't just a superb X-Men adventure, it's a fantastic motion picture, period, and Mangold, Jackman and everyone else involved with its creation should be more than proud of what it is they've accomplished.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: Fans of Marvel, X-Men, and the Wolverine character should be pleased with Logan-it's a strong finale and arguably the best in this highly uneven spin-off series.
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: The result is easily the most varied, earnest and interesting take on a comic book character since The Dark Knight.
reviews.author: Andy Hoglund

reviews.text: [Logan is] really just another exercise in violence featuring Logan's adamantium claws - a trait shared with teenage Laura (Dafne Keen) in overblown action scenes that recall the sickeningly sadistic kiddie assassin movie Kick-Ass.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: No doubt, a reboot is on the way for the X-Men franchise, and the Wolverine character in particular, but make no mistake, Jackman has left big boots to fill and an indelible impression where X marks the spot.
reviews.author: Jeremy Aspinall

reviews.text: Jackman is, once more, superb, holding down the whole film: no matter how battered, gnarled and shrubby he looks, you always root for him. A bit of a beast - but our beast.
reviews.author: David Sexton

reviews.text: A film that, maybe more than anything else, showcases what a fine actor Jackman is. He gives a performance of genuine depth and poignancy.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Logan establishes a new beachhead in comic book cinema wars, somewhere between hectic Avengers spectacle and Deadpool irreverence, a somberness that Batman and Superman haven't mastered.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: While Logan finds a mature tone to carry this final chapter of Wolverine's story, it doesn't come to a conclusion with any more meaning to it than this: People, in general, don't change; more violence will be necessary.
reviews.author: Michael Smith

reviews.text: Well, they are sure sending Wolverine out in style. And a big, oozing blaze of glory.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Raising the stakes on superhero movies by a significant margin, "Logan" could be the cinematic equivalent to Frank Miller's legendary comic book "The Dark Knight Returns."
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Logan elevates itself from a superb superhero film to a superb film, period, one that all superhero films to come should strive to emulate.
reviews.author: Kanin Srimaneekulroj

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman goes out in R-rated style with Logan.Just don't buy into the 'Best Superhero Movie Ever' hype. Not even close.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: There will doubtlessly be other superhero movies to follow this sort of tragic trajectory, but they won't have the luxury of utilizing an actor we've been watching for nearly two decades in the role, finally closing it out his way.
reviews.author: Piers Marchant

reviews.text: Simply put, "Logan" is arguably the best "X-Men" movie of the bunch. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Profanity, Nudity, etc. - also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Logan is a fine example of the superhero film where fantasy is tame and reality is wild.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: It's the Wolverine movie some fans have been waiting for for nearly two decades.
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: Credit where it's due: this is a grown-up movie that's a drama first and superhero story second. Maybe you shouldn't give points for effort, but maybe you should when you're talking about a subset of films as locked-in to their formulas as these.
reviews.author: Jason Bailey

reviews.text: For those who want to see their superheroes grow up, Logan is a satisfying vision of what that real-world mutant would be.
reviews.author: Kirk Baird

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman and Patrick Stewart take the opportunity to go into far more depth and weight to characters they have played umpteen times over the past two decades.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: "Logan" is one heck of a movie, easily rating as the best X-Men-related movie to come along.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: Jackman twists the pain at the centre of the hero's struggle into remarkably uncomfortable places for a blockbuster.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: While there are action sequences, the quiet moments work best . One gets a "Shawshank" vibe as the men longingly look into one another's eyes expressing platonic love as only two original X-Men can. Yes, fanboy, this movie is for you, and count me in.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: The picture sounds a deep human note that might be what you'll remember most fondly when looking back on it.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: Jackman's performance is Clint Eastwood-esque, and the lines in Jackman's face tell the story of his worn character; he plays Wolverine as a man at the end of his line, adding at least a decade to his 48 years.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: The film pulls out all the stops to deliver an emotionally and viscerally satisfying experience. It works so well it easily qualifies as the best movie of the entire X-Men franchise as well as one of the best in the increasingly tired superhero genre.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: A fitting finale for Jackman that sometimes falters in its urge to please.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Combining these two blade runners, working side by side, is a recipe for stunts, special effects, and big box office.
reviews.author: Steve Crum

reviews.text: Logan is not a superhero movie. It's a neo-western with a tragic, reluctant anti-hero
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: It is uncompromising in its brutality and fearless in its reverence of these iconic characters. It's a testament to the power of storytelling, and what creative freedom can produce. Goodbye bub. You've changed superhero movies forever.
reviews.author: Rohan Naahar

reviews.text: The best superhero movie ever is more about the curse of super powers than super powers. Maybe that's why it's the best superhero movie ever.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: Nobody needs to call Logan a masterpiece. But it's heartening to see a blockbuster-minded movie this well made, one that ticks all its genre boxes and delivers a potent emotional punch.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: I can't think of another superhero film where the main subject is the heroes getting old and losing their powers, nor of one that opens with their world apparently coming to an end.
reviews.author: Sarah Boslaugh

reviews.text: Logan is as understated a masterpiece as there's ever been, delivering the Wolverine film we've all been waiting for, and if this truly is Hugh Jackman's final time playing him, he has definitely left the series on a high note.
reviews.author: Ryan Pollard

reviews.text: Well-made and thoughtful, and it pays off so splendidly in the final fifteen minutes one wishes what preceded this climax could have been its equal. Where "Logan" leads is inevitable and necessary, but it doesn't make it any easier.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: A film of rare power and tension in this subgenre and a farewell to the measure of that iconic character called Wolverine. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: It's as if its director, in his effort to be profound, ends up being annoying. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: The bloodiest Marvel movie ever. It's by no means a despicable work, by far the best X-men film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jordi Costa

reviews.text: Director James Mangold shoots and orchestrates action with an appreciable clarity, and when he synchs up with the pounding drums of Marco Beltrami's score, the mayhem has a lively intensity.
reviews.author: James Robert Douglas

reviews.text: Logan is a beautiful send-off for the proud, tormented warrior who was so recognizably human underneath his claws.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: Slow and depressing, and not in a good way.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: It strikes a sombre, gritty tone from the start to take the audience on a dark and rather brutal road trip. So while it feels rather long and repetitive, the movie also has a strong emotional kick.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Unlike any other comic book movie made so far, but for all that ambition and gratuitous violence, Logan is a taxing and overindulgent experience.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: With dignity and grace, Jackman says sayonara to this signature role. It's clear how much physicality and humor he passed on to this mashup of comic book action and political allegory, in his portrait of the ronin with six swords.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: It's not often that a film embedded in a franchise is allowed to break from its shackles to offer something genuinely different... which makes Logan, the final outing for Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, even more remarkable.
reviews.author: Rob Carnevale

reviews.text: Logan is a superhero movie like no other.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: With its mix of neo-Western and quasi-samurai tropes, Logan isn't just the best X-Men movie in forever; it's one of the best comic-book-sourced movies we've seen in some time.
reviews.author: Joe Gross

reviews.text: Jackman, who first starred as Logan/Wolverine 17 years ago, turns in a great performance. He's clearly relishing the chance to play the character one last time in a project that's not just a good superhero movie, but a good movie, period.
reviews.author: Scott D. Pierce

reviews.text: Finally, 17 years since it all began, we get the payoff.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: Through one simple, emotionally satisfying revelation late in the movie, Logan argues that stories like this - like the Westerns before them - can be culturally crucial because they give us hope when we need it the most.
reviews.author: Eric Melin

reviews.text: The darkest and arguably the best of the Wolverine adventures is an emotional journey that's marked by bursts of bloody violence.
reviews.author: Roger Tennis

reviews.text: Logan was written by Scott Frank, Mr. Mangold and Michael Green. Their script is the crucial ingredient of this impressive production, a model of ambition, complexity and old-fashioned showmanship that's matched by Mr. Mangold's direction.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: The fight scenes are entertainingly brutal, but the consequences are bloody and the emotional stakes high. It's an elegiac superhero movie that understands there's no living with killing.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: Ultimately, it's not just a movie for adults because of the death toll, it's one for the grown-ups because it actually engages the emotions. No small feat for a superhero movie.
reviews.author: Tim Evans

reviews.text: Logan, the third Wolverine spinoff from an X-Men movie empire that has grown terribly long in the tooth (or is that claw?), does a nice job of righting the ship with this elegiac closing chapter.
reviews.author: Tom Meek

reviews.text: The only problem with calling it the boldest and most affecting superhero flick in many years is that it's barely a superhero movie at all.
reviews.author: Chris Klimek

reviews.text: The film celebrates the medium by taking itself seriously, with an added hint of apology for the genre's earlier sins. Best of all, there's an element of risk.
reviews.author: Peter Hartlaub

reviews.text: The film is, above all else, a refreshing change of pace from the usual, comic-book superhero fodder. It's melancholy and introspective...
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Provides the tough, adult version of Wolverine that fans have been wanting for a long time...
reviews.author: Tony Stamp

reviews.text: Even as the formulaic plotline of government/corporations versus the disenfranchised that X-Men have used for seventeen years now begins to surface, it fails to diminish from the intensity and excitement rampant throughout every scene.
reviews.author: Michael O'Sullivan

reviews.text: The startling trick here is to turn Wolverine into a self-destructive and fed-up old man... And director Mangold, incredibly, makes you buy Wolverine's "where are the mutants of yesteryear" melancholy.
reviews.author: Jeff Simon

reviews.text: Logan is a family drama, an action thriller and an epic superhero story. If this is indeed Jackman's last Wolverine film, he's going out in heartfelt, high-class style.
reviews.author: Sandy Cohen

reviews.text: Like Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, the flicker of hope Logan offers is so fragile, it's hard to believe it won't be snuffed out... Superhero movies, it seems, can no longer be counted upon as a cinematic escape.
reviews.author: Vicky Roach

reviews.text: Logan is kind of a special superhero movie, in a good way, and if Jackman holds to his stated intention to make it his Wolverine swan song, he's going out not with a whimper but a bang.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: On its own terms, Logan is a crackerjack piece of work: The dialogue is crisp, the staging snappy, and the action scenes really pop.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: The gloomiest and grisliest of the X-Men franchise is expertly crafted in detail but overlong, dreary and dispiriting as a whole.
reviews.author: Jim Lane

reviews.text: For what it is, Logan is strong stuff, and a classy sendoff to Wolverine. Let's just hope that Marvel and Jackman let sleeping wolves lie.
reviews.author: Stephen Rebello

reviews.text: A tale that is as psychically violent as it is physically so, it is a sharp descant to the earlier films in the franchise as it presents a brooding, aging Logan very near the end of his existential rope.
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Jackman and Stewart are at the top of their game, and Dafne Keen as Laura makes the most of her watchful, silence-laden role.
reviews.author: Rich Heldenfels

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman sharpens his claws in every sense of the word and delivers killer work.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: For once, a film derived from a Marvel source gives you something solid to hang on to.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: This is the collapse of the sprawling X-Men family that Wolverine only begrudgingly joined in the first place.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: ... It boldly blazes its own trail, refusing to be reined in by what has come before.
reviews.author: Greg Maki

reviews.text: Logan offers an element of completion, and an intriguingly different take on the material. It is also, along with the FX series Legion, a sign of the maturation of comics on screen, for better or worse.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Director James Mangold, returning after the second installment, The Wolverine, orchestrates several jaw-dropping action sequences, heightened by Jackman's and Keen's intense performances and by Marco Beltrami's taut and plunky score.
reviews.author: Leah Pickett

reviews.text: If this is indeed Jackman's final appearance as Logan, he's going out in style.
reviews.author: Calvin Wilson

reviews.text: In erratic, passionate bursts, I loved Logan, for the tenderness of Wolverine and Xavier's long goodbye to each other, and to us.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: "Logan" is good enough that you might forget it's a comic-book movie.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: Two and a quarter hours of lycanthropic hokum with fun moments.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: Jackman and Stewart's fond, easy dynamic helps to balance some very provocative brutality, as the movie pushes Wolverine's berserk nature to graphic new extremes.
reviews.author: Tom Russo

reviews.text: It runs long and has a bit more action than it really needs, but Logan will likely find a spot among the best comic book adaptations to grace a movie theater.
reviews.author: Britton Peele

reviews.text: "Logan" is a serious take on the comic-book genre, the Marvel Cinematic Universe in particular, and it's a good one.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: It wants its stand-alone story of Wolverine and Professor Xavier to be taken seriously as authentic drama. And, to a surprising extent, it succeeds.
reviews.author: Kenneth Turan

reviews.text: While the relationship among the central trio is strong, the lengthy plot heads off on too many detours, and the serious tone, while refreshing, gets a bit numbing over time.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: A violent, gritty and soulful tribute to the character behind so much of this franchise's enduring popularity.
reviews.author: Tom Glasson

reviews.text: With his glimpse into what superhero movies can be, James Mangold has given us something sadly lacking in recent genre entries: hope.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Logan provides a fitting finale to the Wolverine franchise. It isn't often a Marvel superhero gets to saddle up, tip his hat and ride off into the proverbial sunset.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: The finest Marvel film so far since Stan Lee's empire moved into the multiplexes, and it's almost up there with Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy
reviews.author: John Byrne

reviews.text: The last of Logan is also the best of Logan.
reviews.author: Adam Sweeting

reviews.text: Mangold's direction helps to take this particular genre to another level that is poignant and, at times, tragic.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: Logan is not really asking us to consider the plight of vulnerable children, it's encouraging us to get off on it.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: Logan is the violent, brutal and gory R-rated Wolverine movie 40-something fanboys have always wanted. It's most definitely for grown-ups. It's also very, very good.
reviews.author: David Frese

reviews.text: If this really is Jackman's last big-screen adventure as Wolverine, it's an excellent and fitting finale.
reviews.author: Julie Washington

reviews.text: Jackman's performance is likably physical, with Logan on the verge of dying throughout. He takes a ton of punishment.
reviews.author: Paul Byrnes

reviews.text: You don't have to be a comic superhero fan to enjoy this movie -- watch it for the outstanding performances by Jackman, Stewart and Keen. This one's a gripping finale to Wolverine's indomitable journey.
reviews.author: Zeenia Baria

reviews.text: Logan is deadly serious, and while its gamer-style killing sprees are meant to be excitingly brutal, I found them numbing and, in the climax, borderline offensive.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: This is the Wolverine movie that unlocks the explosive violence that was always inside the Marvel character but, frustratingly, never let out.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: Of the three Wolverine movies, this is the best. I'm glad I saw it and glad it's over.
reviews.author: Edward Johnson-Ott

reviews.text: Logan makes for a better character study than superhero adventure.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: Jackman, who's always been remarkably human in this superhuman role, is as good as he's ever been at finding the beating heart underneath all that adamantium. I will miss the hell out of him.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: Despite tonal missteps, a major one serving as the film's transition to the third act, Logan is a thinking man's superhero flick: the best "gritty" offering we've had since The Dark Knight Returns.
reviews.author: Walker MacMurdo

reviews.text: Here, at last, was a Wolverine story that felt like the comics I remembered. And not just that: it's a comic-book superhero movie that genuinely pushes the form forward
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: I never thought I'd say this about a superhero movie, but bring a hankie.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: Overall, this is a surprisingly strong entry in the X-Men canon, radically different where it counts, but always respectfully honouring Wolverine's hard-earned heritage as a character.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: It's just as much an arthouse drama, or a prestige picture, as it is a big-budget, action-fantasy movie starring Wolverine. And how many other superhero movies can you say that about?
reviews.author: Germain Lussier

reviews.text: It's difficult to imagine how this could be improved upon. An unmissable treat for comic fans, but a thoroughly enjoyable thriller in its own right.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: Easily the best entry in the sprawling X-Men franchise, and arguably the best superhero film since The Dark Knight offered a similar sense of refreshing thoughtfulness.
reviews.author: Mike Scott

reviews.text: Logan makes sadism fun!
reviews.author: Damien Straker

reviews.text: Discarding the spandex and playful camaraderie of the X-Men for a grizzled, dustball future where mutants are all but extinct, it is also the series' most nihilistic chapter.
reviews.author: James Marsh

reviews.text: It's Unforgiven, with claws.
reviews.author: Jonathan L. Fischer

reviews.text: The action scenes are visceral and raw, however those are few, far between and spoiled by the trailers. The movie is too small, insular and grim to be completely enjoyable. Worth a watch once, but won't hold up on repeat viewings.
reviews.author: Michelle Alexandria

reviews.text: Easily the best Wolverine film, Logan is violent, vicious and ruthless, but with heart and hope at its center, and probably the best X-Men film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Logan is the best argument in years for making movies out of comic books.
reviews.author: Daniel Eagan

reviews.text: Don't be put off by the slow beginning. Don't be deterred by Logan's incessant bitterness. At some point the film builds to a thoroughly satisfying ending.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: Logan deserves praise for its action scenes, delivering R-rated violence with enough blood to feel weighty without being an egregious gore-fest.
reviews.author: Gavia Baker-Whitelaw

reviews.text: The superhero category has gotten more boring as it's gotten more popular, but "Logan" suggests an escape from escapism, a restoration of the human element in blockbusters, a stripped-down return to the feel of 1970s Clint Eastwood pictures.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: What's special about Logan is that it manages to deliver the visceral goods, all the hardcore Wolverine action its fans could desire, while still functioning as a surprisingly thoughtful, even poignant drama-a terrific movie ...
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: Just because a comic book flick takes the dirt road less traveled doesn't mean it's a cinematic work of art.
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: This is the X-Men movie - and the Wolverine - I've been waiting for. Violent, thrilling, funny, heartbreaking; everything's up for grabs and it leaves us breathless. Logan inflicts emotional wounds on the audience, yet keeps us wildly entertained.
reviews.author: Diva Velez

reviews.text: After a while, with all that relentless drudgery and all the maimings, it becomes a bit much.
reviews.author: Will Leitch

reviews.text: Let's cut straight to the chase and not mope around the point. "Logan" - the final chapter in the saga of the X-Men's Wolverine - is the best superhero-related movie since "The Dark Knight" nearly a decade ago.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: Instead of putting the emphasis on superhero superpowers, Mangold delves deeply into these characters' human-scale vulnerabilities.
reviews.author: Soren Andersen

reviews.text: "Logan" synthesises comic book characters into the real world in a way that's only been reached in what Roger Ebert called the "engrossing tragedy" of the "The Dark Knight."
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: One of the best superhero movies, definitely the best from X-Men. More importantly, the first great film of the year. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: The X-Men series - the entire superhero genre - has never seen a film like Logan before: raw, rageful, tormented, human. Best of the series yet.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman has been Wolverine for over 17 years, and yet he found a way to deliver a [new] version of the character...in quite possibly the best performance of his career.
reviews.author: Jacqueline Coley

reviews.text: Logan is the rare blockbuster that could be a game-changer. It will certainly change the way we look at other superhero movies and how history judges the entire MCU and DC Universe of films.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: When Logan and Laura unleash their furious scythes nothing feels settled or satisfied. The world grinds on, fruitlessly weary and wild.
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: One of next year's nominees for Best Actor must go to Jackman. His Logan is as moving and complex as dramatic characters demand. Boyd Holbrook is a charismatic villain.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: Mangold and Jackman bring integrity and ability to an increasingly stale and pandering genre, closing out Jackman's Wolverine with dignity and poise. That's more that most of us can hope for when we're 170-plus years old, right?
reviews.author: Patrick Kolan

reviews.text: This is NOT your father's Wolverine!"
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: Logan is not just a great superhero film, it's a great film, period.
reviews.author: Travis Johnson

reviews.text: A bruisingly good elegy
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: A truly affecting and gritty human story.
reviews.author: Amy West

reviews.text: Jackman's is a revelatory performance that paradoxically works as a worthy send-off yet leaves us wishing for more.
reviews.author: Gary Dowell

reviews.text: Legitimate character drama that happens to include bouts of gratuitous murder and mayhem.
reviews.author: J.R. Kinnard

reviews.text: Jackman taps into the darkest elements of the character but never loses the humanity, and if this is his last outing, he's gone out with a perfect, heart-breaking portrayal full of rage and grief.
reviews.author: Jonathan Hatfull

reviews.text: It's not a film calculated to be a people-pleaser, but it is an appropriately intense end to a character defined by the tenacity and ferocity of a wolverine.
reviews.author: Jim Vorel

reviews.text: I feel the third act is not nearly as strong as the first two, but the climax is damned near perfect and a great send off for Jackman and the Wolverine character.
reviews.author: Anthony Ray Bench

reviews.text: It doesn't look like a superhero movie, but rather a good "American" film, where the important thing is the construction of the internal bonds that are tying the protagonists. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alejandro G. Calvo

reviews.text: The poisonous political climate of 2017 and persecution of a 2029 comic book world collide with devastating force.
reviews.author: Matthew Anderson

reviews.text: director James Mangold has wrapped the trilogy with R-rated violence and gore while also giving his protagonist that which has always eluded him...what's so refreshing about "Logan" is how divorced it is from the genre that spawned it.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Logan is a punch in the gut in all the right ways.
reviews.author: Alan Scherstuhl

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman says goodbye to Wolverine in a more than dignified way and exceeding everyone's expectations. Maybe even his own. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carlos Jesús González

reviews.text: A sensational film worthy of having a special place next to titles as 'Unbreakable', 'The Incredibles' and 'The Dark Knight'. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: An interesting meditation on life and death, periodically interrupted by excessive, skin-slashing, bone-snapping ultraviolence.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: At the end of the day it's still just a comic book movie bragging about how it's no typical comic book movie. Yes, and?
reviews.author: Matt Prigge

reviews.text: Logan is a dark and thrilling finale for Wolverine. Director James Mangold brings stark realism to the comic genre.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: Mangold has open-heartedly embraced the use of violence, but this is light years away from the tongue-in-cheek gore-fest of Deadpool
reviews.author: Joseph Walsh

reviews.text: It's hard to fathom that we will no longer see the buff Jackman preening with those shiny steel claws, but he is getting older, so I suppose we should let him retire this character from his repertoire.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: There's a good reason to see "Logan", and also some good reasons not to see "Logan".
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Although it's a "super-hero movie", Logan is not about action, but about characters and their relationships. [Full review in Portuguese.]
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: It's something no-one could have expected: a creatively risky superhero movie. And it deserves to pay off.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Logan is full of juicy surprises. But what impresses most is how, for once, this is a comic-book film that has the guts to wrap things up.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: If you're open to seeing a new, previously unknown Wolverine, Logan is going to stay with you for a long time.
reviews.author: Lauren O'Callaghan

reviews.text: Logan is a Marvel movie with a bit of soul and some true grit. Presumed to be the final outing for Wolverine, it plays more like a late period John Wayne western than it does like a conventional superhero film.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: Jackman does his usual gruff protagonist as well as expected, but it's other performances that really stand out; mostly notably Stewart -- haggard, vulnerable but never skipping out on his humour.
reviews.author: George Simpson

reviews.text: The best X-Men movie since 2003's X2.
reviews.author: Emily St. James

reviews.text: This is the Wolverine movie fans have always wanted to see; period.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: The grim side of human nature is all over James Mangold's Logan. But that doesn't necessarily make it a good movie.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: The weight of graphic, grotesque violence hangs over the entire movie. But the daring emotional violence lingers longer, well after the lights go down on the final shot.
reviews.author: Tasha Robinson

reviews.text: When it comes to playing a properly magnetic anti-hero with a gruff '70s-cinema exterior and a dark reservoir of inner depth, Jackman really is the best at what he does.
reviews.author: Dan Jolin

reviews.text: Star Hugh Jackman isn't just giving us the definitive X-Men movie; it could just be the definitive comic book movie.
reviews.author: Mark Daniell

reviews.text: Operatic and also deeply personal, Logan is one of the true great films of the superhero genre, among the best films of 2017 to date, and a rousing send-off for the old guard while ushering in the future of the X-Men franchise.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: From the very first shot to the very last, every frame feels perfectly rendered and absolutely necessary to the narrative trajectory.
reviews.author: Allyson Johnson

reviews.text: There's a resonant motif in Logan that times have changed for the worst, but this dystopian world revives the humanity in these characters, a development that's all for the best.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: If you remove the graphic violence, it's not all that different from 'The Wolverine,' with Logan again finding someone to protect after turning his back on life.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: Logan is way bloodier than Deadpool, yet still artful in the way The Raid movies turn rhythmic stabbing into a brutal ballet.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: Mangold confidently places the film in the context of a neo-Western, painting Logan and Professor X as two men who have been left behind by the world they once defined.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: It's an amazing swan song for the Wolverine character, and for Jackman, and perhaps the best X-Men movie yet.
reviews.author: Scott Collura

reviews.text: Jackman clearly adores the character, and he embraces the chance to essentially reinvent the mutton-chopped slayer for one final hurrah. It's strange to think that this might stand as one of his greatest performances, but so it goes.
reviews.author: David Jenkins

reviews.text: Easily the best Wolverine outing, Logan is The Dark Knight of the mutant-filled X-franchise, a gripping film that transcends the comic-book genre by saying something important ...
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: A rather brilliant mesh of dystopian and superhero tropes that proves to be as entertaining as it is timely.
reviews.author: Rory O'Connor

reviews.text: I'm not speaking hyperbolically when I say that Logan is the best, most exciting X-Men film to have made it to the big screen.
reviews.author: Keisha Hatchett

reviews.text: This is honestly one of the best comic book movies of all time.
reviews.author: Kyle Anderson

reviews.text: "Logan" self-consciously aspires to retire the steel-clawed hero with epic grandeur, and the results are often rousingly bleak. And yet, the risks taken only make the formulaic redemption story and cliched emotional underpinnings increasingly frustrating.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: Mangold gives our grumpy old friend quite a send-off, a blood-drenched stab-a-thon that frequently hits bone.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: X-Men movie franchise connections aside, Logan is a grisly and somber character drama that sends off Hugh Jackman's Wolverine on a high note.
reviews.author: Sandy Schaefer

reviews.text: Logan is a searing, claws-out action drama that hits hard, chews grit and leaves an everlasting impression.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: What Deadpool awakened in audiences a year ago, this thirst for blood, can be credited as paving the way for Logan, which picks up the cause of violence and accelerates it considerably.
reviews.author: Neil Miller

reviews.text: By grounding the film's action, and painting on a relatively small-scale canvas, 'Logan' raises the bar on the types of stories you can tell with superheroes -- thereby redefining what the term Superhero Movie even means in the year 2017.
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: Seamlessly melding Marvel mythology with Western mythology, James Mangold has crafted an affectingly stripped-down standalone feature, one that draws its strength from Hugh Jackman's nuanced turn as a reluctant, all but dissipated hero.
reviews.author: Sheri Linden

reviews.text: Logan is a forthright, muscular movie which preserves the X-Men's strange, exotic idealism.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: It's both the most violent film in the series and the most sentimental one. When it's not showering you in blood, it's trying to make you spill tears.
reviews.author: Chris Nashawaty

reviews.text: The analog pace and elemental story work for it. Each time the violence explodes, it's slashingly satisfying, because it's earned, and also because Mangold knows just how to stage it.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: The violence in "Logan" isn't played for kicks, like it was in "Deadpool." It's grave and serious and sometimes hard to watch, which fits in with the overall tone of this grim, surprisingly downbeat movie.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: Logan is the movie that finally satisfies the wish fulfillment of those superhero movie conversations that that speculate on what a hard R-rated superhero movie would look like with a major established character.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: Perhaps it's just the novelty, but that explicit violence and salty language (Professor X turns out to be quite the potty-mouth as well) adds a bit of much-needed fizz to the Wolverine sub-franchise.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Logan is a great addition to the X-Men films and it should please adult fans of the series.
reviews.author: Scott Chitwood

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman's last Wolverine story ends on a grim, gritty and ultra-violent note that wins points both for being cinematic and for being so different.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: James Mangold has re-teamed with Jackman for an intense Western that re-introduces the brutish X-Men as a cowboy, wracked with remorse and reckoning with redemption.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Logan is Hugh Jackman's finest work as Wolverine, and a movie full of ambition, emotion, and drama.
reviews.author: Alan Cerny

reviews.text: Hugh Jackman is all growl and gristle, Logan's lovable grouchiness turned to outright rage.
reviews.author: Tom Huddleston

reviews.text: Better as an agitated Western than as a fading superhero movie (or a listless cross-country chase), the most cantankerous X-Man's final outing is a scaled-back affair that nevertheless knows how to swing for the fences.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: It looks like a small production but really, it feels like the biggest X-Men movie. It has more to say than any other installment. It leads to meaningful conclusions. It is brutal and bold and it shouldn't be missed.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Easily the best Wolverine movie.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: The movie fans have been asking for ever since Hugh Jackman first put on his claws.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: "Logan" is the bleakest vision of Wolverine yet, but also hands down the best treatment the character has received on the big screen in the fifteen plus years Hugh Jackman has inhabited the role.
reviews.author: Kevin Jagernauth

reviews.text: Logan is without question the best superhero movie in years, and certainly the most ambitious one since Christopher Nolan hung up the cape.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: Logan is a mighty swan song for Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, a tour de force for Patrick Stewart and an amazing debut from young Dafne Keen. Don't bring your kids. Do bring your hankies.
reviews.author: Rosie Fletcher

reviews.text: Logan is a total anomaly. James Mangold turns the key on the tawdry, predictable superhero formula, delivering both his best film to date and one of the most game-changing comic book adaptations to ever leave the pages.
reviews.author: Michael Roffman

reviews.text: Brutal, raw & emotionally satisfying. Logan is up there with the best comic book movies ever made.
reviews.author: Jon Lyus

reviews.text: It recognizes that the thinly veiled secret of Wolverine's loner act is that he's always been a cog of some kind.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

synopsis: In the near future, a weary Logan (Hugh Jackman) cares for an ailing Professor X (Patrick Stewart) at a remote outpost on the Mexican border. His plan to hide from the outside world gets upended when he meets a young mutant (Dafne Keen) who is very much like him. Logan must now protect the girl and battle the dark forces that want to capture her.
